document.docTitle: Twenty years later: Biodiversity of marine symbiotic Siphonostomatoida (Copepoda) off Southern Africa

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Twenty years later: Biodiversity of marine symbiotic Siphonostomatoida (Copepoda) off Southern Africa

emphasis.docTitle: Twenty years later: Biodiversity of marine symbiotic Siphonostomatoida ( Copepoda ) off Southern Africa

paragraph.emphasis: Department of Biodiversity, University of Limpopo , South Africa

subSection.paragraph: Siphonostomatoida ( Copepoda ) consists of 40 families of symbionts infecting vertebrates (17 families) and invertebrates (23 families) found mostly in marine habitats. In 2004, a list was compiled of all the reported families, genera and species symbiotic with marine fish in Southern African waters. Since this was done 20 years ago, it is necessary to re-evaluate the progress made in 20 years regarding our knowledge of the diversity of marine siphonostomatoids. To assess the current knowledge, the 2004 list was updated with reports published since 2004 as well as with new host and locality records including species with changes in taxonomy. Additionally, species collected but unreported as well as species previously reported but with new hosts and/or localities were also added. Currently reports include 16 families, 75 genera and 234 species. However, amongst these are reports of only two families (3 species) infecting invertebrates. Even though the report includes 71 additional species it still compares poorly with the about 2 274 accepted species, especially regarding species infecting invertebrates. Considering South Africa’s wealth in possible marine host species, examination of more hosts (especially marine teleosts and invertebrates) will definitely result in an increase in the current knowledge about the biodiversity of marine siphonostomatoids off Southern Africa.
Key words: Siphonostomatoids , parasitic , vertebrates , invertebrates , oceans

Siphonostomatoida Burmeister, 1835 is one of the 10 orders of the Copepoda and consists of symbiotic members found on most animal groups, especially in marine habitats. The siphonostomatoids (about 2 274 species) currently comprise about 15% of all known copepod species (14 891 species) ( Walter & Boxshall 2024 ). Of the 40 families of the Siphonostomatoida , representatives of 17 are almost exclusively found on marine vertebrates, while the members of most of the remaining families are found symbiotic with invertebrates ( Boxshall & Halsey 2004 ).

Additionally, hosts caught in the Indian and Atlantic Oceans off South Africa since 2004 were examined for infection by siphonostomatoids. Collected specimens were examined and identified and new records of siphonostomatoids and/or hosts as well as new geographic locations are reported ( Table 2 ).

Significant changes are found in especially the Caligidae (including representatives previously part of Euryphoridae (see Dippenaar 2004 )) ( Dojiri & Ho 2013 ). Furthermore, additional reports are included of symbionts collected mostly from Teleostei but also elasmobranchs to Caligidae (15 species – excluding new combinations) ( Table 1 ). Additionally,
Caligus arii Bassett-Smith, 1898
(recorded by Barnard (1948)) previously synonymized with
C . dakari van Beneden, 1892
(see Dippenaar 2004 ) needs verification as
C . arii
is a valid species ( Hayes et al. 2021 ). Synonymies include
Caligus cf. affinis Heller, 1866
( Dippenaar 2004 ) synonymized with
C . temnodontis Brian, 1924
(
Özak et al . 2010
);
C . alalongae Krøyer, 1863
( Dippenaar 2004 ) synonymized with
C . productus Dana, 1852
( Boxshall & Bernot 2023 );
C . biseriodentatus Shen, 1957
( Dippenaar 2004 ) synonymized with
C . pauliani Nuñes-Ruivo & Fourmanoir, 1956
( Boxshall & Bernot 2023 );
C . rotundigenitalis Yu, 1933
( Dippenaar 2004 ) synonymized with
C . torpedinis Heller, 1865
( Boxshall & Bernot 2023 );
Lepeophtheirus natalensis Kensley & Grindley, 1973
( Dippenaar 2004 ) synonymized with
Caligus furcisetifer Redkar, Rangnekar & Murti, 1949
( Hayes et al. 2021 );
Pseudocaligus apodus Brian, 1924
( Dippenaar 2004 ) synonymized with
Caligus apodus (Brian, 1924) ( Dojiri & Ho 2013 )
; and
Sciaenophilus tenuis van Beneden, 1852
( Dippenaar 2004 ) synonymized with
Caligus tenuis (van Beneden, 1852) (
Özak et al . 2017
)
. Even though
C . mauritanicus
was synonymized with
C . dakari ( Boxshall & El-Rashidy 2009 )
, specimens reported from Southern African waters (see Dippenaar 2004 ) need closer examination according to
Hayes et al . (2021)
as re-examination of material of
C . mauritanicus
from
Pomatomus saltatrix
was identified as
C . temnodontis (
Özak et al . 2010
)
.

In the Eudactylinidae , five new species reports collected from elasmobranchs are included, while the family Hyponeoidae is included with one new species report. In the family Kroyeriidae reports of an additional six species are included ( Table 1 ).

Several taxonomic changes are also found in the Lernaeopodidae .
Albionella etmopteri (Yamaguti, 1939) ( Dippenaar 2004 )
was synonymized with
Neoalbionella etmopteri (Yamaguti, 1939)
;
Alella gibbosa van Niekerk & Olivier, 1995
and
A . macrotrachelus (Brian, 1906) ( Dippenaar 2004 )
were both synonymized with
A . pagelli (Krøyer, 1863) ( Dippenaar 2016 )
;
Brachiella dentici Nuñes-Ruivo, 1962
( Dippenaar 2004 ) was synonymized with
Parabrachiella dentici (Nuñes-Ruivo, 1962)
;
B . genypteri Capart, 1959
( Dippenaar 2004 ) is synonymized with
P . supplicans ( Barnard, 1955 )
;
B . lithognathae Kensley & Grindley, 1973
( Dippenaar 2004 ) is a synonymy of
Sparidicola lithognathae (Kensley & Grindley, 1973)
;
B . supplicans Barnard, 1955
( Dippenaar 2004 ) is a synonym of
P . supplicans ( Barnard, 1955 )
;
Charopinus bicaudatus (Krøyer, 1837) ( Dippenaar 2004 )
was synonymized with
Pseudocharopinus bicaudatus (Krøyer, 1837)
;
Clavella pagri (Capart, 1959) ( Dippenaar 2004 )
was synonymized with
Clavellotis pagri (Krøyer, 1863)
;
Clavellopsis appendiculata Kirtisinghe, 1950
( Dippenaar 2004 ) is a synonym of
Isobrachia appendiculata Heegaard, 1947
;
C . fallax (Heller, 1865) ( Dippenaar 2004 )
was synonymized with
Clavellotis fallax (Heller, 1865)
;
C . hostilis (Heller, 1865) ( Dippenaar 2004 )
was synonymized with
Parabrachiella hostilis (Heller, 1865)
;
Neobrachiella chevreuxii (Beneden, 1891) ( Dippenaar 2004 )
was synonymized with
Parabrachiella chevreuxii (Beneden, 1891)
;
N . insidiosa (Heller, 1865) ( Dippenaar 2004 )
is a synonym of
Parabrachiella insidiosa (Heller, 1865)
;
N . merluccii (Bassett-Smith, 1896) ( Dippenaar 2004 )
a synonymy of
Parabrachiella merluccii (Bassett-Smith, 1896) (WoRMS Editorial Board 2023)
; and
Schistobrachia ramosa (Krøyer, 1863)
is a synonym of
S . kabata Dippenaar, 2016
( Dippenaar 2016 ). Additional symbionts reported from hosts belonging to the family Lernaeopodidae (11 species, excluding new combinations) are included ( Table 1 ).

In the family Lernanthropidae fewer taxonomic changes were made with
Lernanthropus trachuri Brian, 1903
( Dippenaar 2004 ) being synonymized with
Lernanthropinus caranxi (Hesse, 1878)
;
Lernanthropus ecclesi Kensley & Grindley 1973
( Dippenaar 2004 ) a synonymy of
Lernanthropus micropterygis Richiardi, 1884
; and
Lernanthropus petersi Beneden, 1857
( Dippenaar 2004 ) synonymized with
Sagum petersi (Beneden, 1857) (WoRMS Editorial Board 2024 )
. No new reports were added.

Furthermore, additional reports are included of symbionts collected from hosts to Pennellidae (eight species), Sphyriidae (nine species) and Trebiidae (one species). Members of Cancerillidae (two species) and Nicotoidae (one species), symbionts of invertebrate hosts, are also included ( Table 1 ). Apart from new species reports, new host or locality reports since 2004 are also included in the table.

Secondly, a table ( Table 2 ) consisting of collected siphonostomatoids from elasmobranchs and teleosts that were not previously reported from South African waters or previously reported species from new hosts or new geographic locations is compiled. Representatives of seven families are included with additional species recorded for Eudactylinidae (six species), Kroyeriidae (two species), Pandaridae (two species) and Sphyriidae (one species) as well as new host and locality reports for representatives of Caligidae , Eudactylinidae , Lernaeopodidae , Pandaridae and Pseudocycnidae .

Of the 17 families of siphonostomatoids infecting vertebrates ( Boxshall & Halsey 2004 ), representatives of 14 are reported from Southern African water ( Fig. 1 ). In 2004 ( Dippenaar 2004 ) the reported 15 families included the Euryphoridae that now forms part of the Caligidae and the Cecropidae that now is part of the
Pandaridae ( Walter & Boxshall 2024 )
. The newly reported family is Hyponeoidae ( Table 1 ). The families which have not been reported include the Archidactylinidae infecting hagfishes ( Myxiniformes : Myxinidae ) ( Izawa 1996 ), Pseudohatschekiidae collected from deepwater tilefishes (Teleostei: Latilidae ) (
Tang et al . 2010
) and Tanypleuridae infecting the arctic eelpout (Teleostei: Zoarcidae ) ( Kabata 1969 ). The combination of the 2004 ( Dippenaar 2004 ) reports as well as the updates ( Table 1 ) and new reports ( Table 2 ) include 73 different genera and 231 species (excluding reports of unidentified species) from vertebrate hosts. Since the 2004 report ( Dippenaar 2004 ), 15 additional species are reported in the Caligidae , 11 in the Eudactylinidae , one in Hyponeoidae , eight in Kroyeriidae , 11 in Lernaeopodidae , six in Pandaridae , eight in Pennellidae , 10 in Sphyriidae and one in Trebiidae . The family with the most reported species is Caligidae (69 species) which still is very low considering that Caligidae currently has about 499 accepted species ( Walter & Boxshall 2024 ) ( Fig. 1 ). This is followed by the Lernaeopodidae (36 species) currently with about 329 accepted species ( Walter & Boxshall 2024 ) ( Fig. 1 ). From these two examples it is clear that there are still many species to be reported from Southern African waters specifically considering the diversity of possible hosts occurring off South Africa (
Griffiths et al . 2010
).

Additionally, two families i.e. Cancerillidae (two species of the same genus from brittle stars) and Nicothoidae (one species from an amphipod) are also reported from invertebrate hosts ( Table 1 ). Thus, only two of the possible 23 families infecting invertebrates are reported from Southern Africa which clearly indicates a lack in knowledge regarding the diversity of siphonostomatoids infecting invertebrates from the region.

caption.paragraph: FIGURE 1. A comparison of the numbers of genera and species known ( Walter & Boxshall 2024 ) with the numbers reported of the 16 families from Southern Africa.

TABLE 1. Revised table from Dippenaar (2004) including all new information since 2004 (reports, synonymies, and changes in family affiliation) and previously omitted reports (from mammals and invertebrates). (Most species with reference ( Dippenaar 2004 ) are reports from 2004, but with changes in their taxonomy.)

subSection.paragraph: I would like to acknowledge the University of Limpopo for collection and laboratory support and BP Jordaan , T Mangena and MC Lebepe for assistance during sampling trips.
